newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Swedish Riksbank says inflation pressure fallen.
newsitem.headline: Swedish Riksbank says inflation pressure fallen.

text.p: Sweden's central bank, the Riksbank, said on Wednesday inflationary pressures appeared to have eased for various reasons.
But the central bank said in a quarterly newsletter it was still too early to say how inflation trends had changed.
"The inflationary pressure in the Swedish economy could have fallen for several reasons," the newsletter said.
The central banks said part of the drop may be because "the confidence in anti-inflation measures could have increased."

It also said the defence of the crown in 1992, the Riksbank's inflation target of two percent with a one-percentage point leeway in either direction, its repo rate policies and Sweden's European Union membership and improved state finances may have contributed to easing inflation worries.
"It is, however, too early to draw conclusions about how much inflationary pressure in the Swedish economy has decreased, apart from the effects of weak economic trends," it said.
Sweden's June consumer price index (CPI) rose 0.1 percent for a year-on-year rise of 0.8 percent. Since December 1996, CPI has risen 1.2 percent.
